Introduction

In line with the group's values and objectives, the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service has created this Service Level Agreement (SLA) document to provide clarity regarding the services and service levels that the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service will provide service users (both managers and staff).

The Occupational Health and Wellbeing (OH&WB) team are committed to providing the best quality service, to agreed standards and service levels defined in this document within defined financial constraints and to achieve this it is important that all our service users (both managers and employees) understand and adhere to the processes in place. This document highlights the responsibilities of the key stakeholders for each service.

There is a mutual dependency for all contributing parties to fulfil the requirements of the following SLA and in doing so achieve timely and successful outcomes. The OH&WB team has published policies, procedures and forms available on the intranet for guidance and compliance to meet best practice and legal requirements. Whilst a flexible approach will be taken to the provision of service, in order to fulfil site and service requirements, Trust policies will be adhered to at all times.

This SLA is intended as a summary of the principal services offered and not an exclusive list of services. Ad hoc requests will be undertaken where possible, and the OH&WB Team will undertake to work within the spirit of the agreement to deliver appropriate levels of services and the best possible clinical outcomes.

The OH&WB team will report to management and service users on performance against key service levels, volumes of demand requested and key performance indicators (KPIs) will be frequently monitored and reviewed to identify opportunities to further improve.
The OH&WB team will regularly seek service-users feedback on the services and service quality to gather feedback and opportunities to further improve.
Principles
The services and sites agree to adopt the following principles when carrying out this agreement:
To collaborate and co-operate in the delivery of the services
To be accountable, by taking on, managing and accounting to each other for the performance of the respective roles and responsibilities set out in this agreement
To communicate openly about major concerns, issues or opportunities relating to this agreement

To learn, develop and seek to achieve the full potential by sharing information, experience, materials and skills to learn from each other and develop effective working practices, work collaboratively to identify solutions, eliminate duplication of effort, mitigate risk and reduce cost
To act in a timely manner, recognising the time-critical nature of the Services provided under this Agreement and respond accordingly to requests for support and information;
Service description

The  Occupational  Health  and  Wellbeing  Service  (OH&WB  Service)  provides  a comprehensive, equitable OH&WB Service to the Mid and South Essex University Hospitals  Group.  It  aims  to  ensure  staff  in  employment  experience  a  working environment  for  which  they  are  physically  and  psychologically  suited  and  that protects  and  promotes  not  only  the  individual  employee's  health,  but  also  the general wellbeing of the patient, visitor and other employees.

The scope includes and is not limited to: health assessment for work, prevention of ill health, protection of health, promotion of health and well-being, employee health surveillance and education & training.

The  nationally  recognised accredited  quality  standard  for OH&WB is  SEQOHS (safe,  effective,  quality  occupational  health  services).  The   sites  work  to  the accreditation standards although accreditation has been temporarily suspended due to the merging of the OH&WB services; formal accreditation will be applied for as a merged service in The OH&WB Service will be able to provide evidence of conformance with each SEQOHS standard whenever this is requested.

The OH&WB Service contributes to the overall effectiveness of the group of Trusts as a provider of health care. It is the provider of a proactive OH&WB Service and will act at all times in the best interests of the Trusts and its employees.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the corporate directorate

table_items.text: The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) as the Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the CEO is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. The CEO will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.

The Chief People and Organisational Development Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
The Group HR Director for Resourcing and Strategic Planning is responsible for ensuring that the OH&WB service is delivered appropriately and provided with the necessary resources to deliver
the services described in this SLA.
The Associate Director of Occupational Health and Wellbeing

The Associate Director of Occupational Health and Wellbeing is responsible for the implementation and monitoring of this document and to provide expert advice and support to the Trust on occupational health and wellbeing matters.
The role of the Occupational Health Physician and Consultant is to provide clinical support and expertise particularly on issues and cases with aspects of clinical complexity.
Deputy Head and OH&WB Site Leads

The Deputy Head of Service and Site Leads are responsible for operational issues across the Group and in assisting the Associate Director in the implementation and monitoring of this document and the delivery of a quality service.
The role of the Occupational Health Advisor is to provide clinical support, case management, occupational health advice and expertise on issues relating to health and work

data.text: Role and Responsibilities of the site and services teams

table_items.text: Clinical Leads/Heads of Service/ Departmental Managers

Clinical Service Leads and Departmental Managers are responsible for implementing this document in their Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are responsible for ensuring that: Occupational health related policies are available to all employees within the Trust. Employees have access to and aware of the confidential OH&WB Service. Employees are referred following periods of sickness absence in line with the Trust Attendance Management policy. Comprehensive and accurate information is provided to the OH&WB service when requesting a health assessment. Employees are referred when work may be a contributing factor to the individuals' ill health or for work performance issues that may be exacerbated by ill health. They respond in a timely manner to management reports received from the OH&WB Service and they will deal effectively with staff who fail to attend for a planned

All Employees should be aware of this policy and the functions of the OH&WB Service. All employees must attend appointments with the OH&WB service when requested to do so by their line manager, failure to attend to appointments without reason or notice may result in a formal process being invoked. All employees must inform the OH of any changes in their health which may affect their ability to work or the safety of themselves, their colleagues and patients.
